row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de coulomb, lei de Coulomb

row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de dalton, lei de Dalton
row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry and physics) law stating that the pressure exerted by a mixture of gases equals the sum of the partial pressures of the gases in the mixture; the pressure of a gas in a mixture equals the pressure it would exert if it occupied the same volume alone at the same temperature

row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry) the total energy in an assembly of molecules is not distributed equally but is distributed around an average value according to a statistical distribution

row.EN-Gloss: (physics) a law expressing the distribution of energy among the molecules of a gas in thermal equilibrium

row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry) the principle that (at chemical equilibrium) in a reversible reaction the ratio of the rate of the forward reaction to the rate of the reverse reaction is a constant for that reaction
row.EN-Words: equilibrium law, law of chemical equilibrium

row.EN-Gloss: (psychophysics) the concept that the magnitude of a subjective sensation increases proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity; based on early work by E. H. Weber
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Ley de Weber Fechner, Ley de Weber-Fechner

row.PT-Word-Cand: Estatística de Fermi-Dirac, Estatística de fermi-dirac

row.EN-Gloss: a principle of Gestalt psychology that identifies factors leading to particular forms of perceptual organization
row.EN-Words: Gestalt law of organization, Gestalt principle of organization

row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de henry, lei de Henry

row.EN-Gloss: (astronomy) the generalization that the speed of recession of distant galaxies (the red shift) is proportional to their distance from the observer
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Ley de hubble, ley de Hubble

row.EN-Gloss: (astronomy) one of three empirical laws of planetary motion stated by Johannes Kepler
row.EN-Words: Kepler's law of planetary motion, Kepler's law

row.EN-Gloss: a law stating that the orbit of each planet is an ellipse with the sun at one focus of the ellipse

a law concerning the speed at which planets travel; a line connecting a planet to the sun will sweep out equal areas in equal times; "Kepler's second law means that a planet's orbital speed changes with its distance from the sun"
row.EN-Words: Kepler's second law, law of areas, law of equal areas

row.EN-Gloss: a law stating that the ratio of the square of the revolutionary period (in years) to the cube of the orbital axis (in astronomical units) is the same for all planets

(physics) two laws governing electric networks in which steady currents flow: the sum of all the currents at a point is zero and the sum of the voltage gains and drops around any closed circuit is zero
a law affirming that in the long run probabilities will determine performance

row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de Proust, Lei de proust
row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry) law stating that every pure substance always contains the same elements combined in the same proportions by weight
row.EN-Words: law of constant proportion, law of definite proportions

row.EN-Gloss: a law affirming that to continue after a certain level of performance has been reached will result in a decline in effectiveness
(psychology) the principle that behaviors are selected by their consequences; behavior having good consequences tends to be repeated whereas behavior that leads to bad consequences is not repeated
(chemistry) law stating that the proportions in which two elements separately combine with a third element are also the proportions in which they combine together
row.EN-Words: law of equivalent proportions, law of reciprocal proportions

row.EN-Gloss: (physics) the law that states any two bodies attract each other with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them
row.EN-Words: Newton's law of gravitation, law of gravitation

row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry) law stating that when two elements can combine to form more than one compound the amounts of one of them that combines with a fixed amount of the other will exhibit a simple multiple relation
row.EN-Words: Dalton's law, law of multiple proportions
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Ley de las proporciones múltiples, Ley de las proporciones multiples

row.EN-Gloss: (chemistry) the law that states the following principle: the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the molecular concentrations of the reacting substances
(physics) a law governing the relations between states of energy in a closed system

row.PT-Word-Cand: Segunda Lei da Termodinâmica, segunda lei da termodinâmica
row.EN-Gloss: a law stating that mechanical work can be derived from a body only when that body interacts with another at a lower temperature; any spontaneous process results in an increase of entropy
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Segunda Ley de la Termodinámica, Segunda Ley de la Termodinamica, Segunda ley de la termodinamica, segunda ley de la termodinámica

row.PT-Word-Cand: Terceira Lei da Termodinâmica, Terceira lei da termodinâmica
row.EN-Gloss: law stating that the entropy of a substance approaches zero as its temperature approaches absolute zero
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Tercera ley de la termodinámica, Tercera ley de la termodinamica

row.EN-Gloss: the law that if two bodies are in thermal equilibrium with a third body then the first two bodies are in thermal equilibrium with each other

row.PT-Word-Cand: Princípio de Le Châtelier, Princípio de Le Chatelier, Princípio de le châtelier
row.EN-Gloss: the principle that if any change is imposed on a system that is in equilibrium then the system tends to adjust to a new equilibrium counteracting the change
row.EN-Words: Le Chatelier principle, Le Chatelier's law, Le Chatelier's principle, Le Chatelier-Braun principle
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Principio de Le Châtelier, Principio de Le Chatelier

row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de Gresham, Lei de gresham
row.EN-Gloss: (economics) the principle that when two kinds of money having the same denominational value are in circulation the intrinsically more valuable money will be hoarded and the money of lower intrinsic value will circulate more freely until the intrinsically more valuable money is driven out of circulation; bad money drives out good; credited to Sir Thomas Gresham
row.SPA-Words-Sug: Ley de Gresham, Ley de gresham

row.EN-Gloss: (genetics) one of two principles of heredity formulated by Gregor Mendel on the basis of his experiments with plants; the principles were limited and modified by subsequent genetic research
the position of member of an honorary academy
members of a pair of homologous chromosomes separate during the formation of gametes and are distributed to different gametes so that every gamete receives only one member of the pair
each member of a pair of homologous chromosomes separates independently of the members of other pairs so the results are random
(physics) the principle that a measured quantity of mass is equivalent (according to relativity theory) to a measured quantity of energy
rule for calculating an expected delivery date; subtract three months from the first day of the last menstrual period and add seven days to that date
one of three basic laws of classical mechanics
row.EN-Words: Newton's law of motion, Newton's law, law of motion

row.EN-Gloss: a body remains at rest or in motion with a constant velocity unless acted upon by an external force

row.EN-Gloss: the position of accountant
the rate of change of momentum is proportional to the imposed force and goes in the direction of the force

row.EN-Gloss: action and reaction are equal and opposite

row.EN-Gloss: electric current is directly proportional to voltage and inversely proportional to resistance; I = E/R

row.PT-Word-Cand: Princípio de Pascal, Princípio de pascal, Principio de Pascal
row.EN-Gloss: pressure applied anywhere to a body of fluid causes a force to be transmitted equally in all directions; the force acts at right angles to any surface in contact with the fluid; "the hydraulic press is an application of Pascal's law"
row.EN-Words: Pascal's law of fluid pressures, Pascal's law

row.PT-Word-Cand: Princípio de Exclusão de Pauli, Princípio de exclusão de pauli, princípio de exclusão de Pauli

row.EN-Gloss: the office of admiral
(chemistry) the principle that chemical properties of the elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers

row.PT-Word-Cand: Lei de Planck da Radiação, Lei de Planck da radiação, Lei de planck da radiação
row.EN-Gloss: (physics) the basis of quantum theory; the energy of electromagnetic waves is contained in indivisible quanta that have to be radiated or absorbed as a whole; the magnitude is proportional to frequency where the constant of proportionality is given by Planck's constant

row.EN-Gloss: (physics) an equation that expresses the distribution of energy in the radiated spectrum of an ideal black body
the post of ambassador

(cosmology) the theory that the universe originated sometime between 10 billion and 20 billion years ago from the cataclysmic explosion of a small volume of matter at extremely high density and temperature
(cosmology) the theory that the solar system evolved from a hot gaseous nebula
(cosmology) the theory that the solar system was formed by the gravitational accumulation of planetesimals

(cosmology) the theory that the universe maintains a constant average density with matter created to fill the void left by galaxies that are receding from each other; "the steady state theory has been abandoned in favor of the big bang theory"
row.EN-Words: continuous creation theory, steady state theory

a hypothetical possibility, circumstance, statement, proposal, situation, etc.; "consider the following, just as a hypothetical"

a concept whose truth can be proved; "scientific hypotheses are not facts"

a theoretical sun that moves along the celestial equator at a constant speed and completes its annual course in the same amount of time the real sun takes at variable speeds

(astronomy) Copernicus' astronomical model in which the Earth rotates around the sun
(astronomy) Ptolemy's model of the universe with the Earth at the center

the first pillar of Islam is an affirmation of faith
the second pillar of Islam is prayer; a prescribed liturgy performed five times a day (preferably in a mosque) and oriented toward Mecca
the position of a curate
the third pillar of Islam is fasting (primarily during the month of Ramadan); Muslims abstain from food and drink and gambling and all sensuous pleasures from sunrise to sunset during Ramadan
the fourth pillar of Islam is almsgiving as an act of worship; "the zakat is earmarked for the poor and disabled"

the fifth pillar of Islam is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja; at least once in a lifetime a Muslim is expected to make a religious journey to Mecca and the Kaaba; "for a Muslim the hajj is the ultimate act of worship"
the position of curator
the bright positive masculine principle in Chinese dualistic cosmology; "yin and yang together produce everything that comes into existence"

a vague idea in which some confidence is placed; "his impression of her was favorable"; "what are your feelings about the crisis?"; "it strengthened my belief in his sincerity"; "I had a feeling that she was lying"
the impression that something is present; "he felt the presence of an evil force"

an idea evoked by some experience; "his reaction to the news was to start planning what to do"
an impression (especially one that is artificial or contrived); "he just did it for effect"
at the first glimpse or impression; "at first blush the idea possesses considerable intuitive appeal but on closer examination it fails"
an effect that imitates a sound called for in the script of a play

a special effect created on the stage
an idea accepted as a demonstrable truth

the locus of feelings and intuitions; "in your heart you know it is true"; "her story would melt your bosom"
the power to foresee the future
